full_threads.body:
Hi Criselda,

Thanks so much for checking in, and I hope you had a great weekend too.

Apologies for the slight delay on this - I’m currently checking your questions with the team and will come back to you as soon as I have an update.

In the meantime, if there’s anything else you need, please feel free to let me know. Always happy to help!

Hope you had a great weekend. Thanks for checking this for us!

Do you have access to our CRM Perks account?

Let me know also in case you receive the invoice for our subscription renewal.

Thanks!

Warm regards,

Criselda Romero
Digital Marketing Manager

Hi Criselda,

You are very welcome! I’m so glad to hear the tags are firing perfectly on your end too. It’s always a great feeling to see that data finally flowing in! 😊

Regarding your question about the CRM Perks plugins, I’ve taken a look at both sites for you. Here is what is currently active:
Acouflor:
  • Plugin: Integration for WooCommerce and Salesforce Pro (Version 1.7.4)
  • What it does: This is the professional version that connects your WooCommerce store to Salesforce to sync your order data.
Acoufelt AU:
  • Plugins: You actually have two active here:
    • Integration for WooCommerce and Salesforce (Version 1.7.8)
    • Integration for WooCommerce and Salesforce Pro (Version 1.7.4)
  • Note: Both are currently active, with the standard version set to auto-update.

I hope that helps! Please let me know if you need anything else or if you'd like me to look into anything further for those integrations. Have a great rest of the day!

Hi Adriane

Amazing! Thank you so much for resolving the issue.

I've tested it as well and the tags are now firing 😊

I also wanted to ask if you can check if we have any current WordPress plugin under CRM Perks for either Acouflor or Acoufelt website?

Thanks!

Warm regards,

Criselda Romero
Digital Marketing Manager



T: +61 1800 626 462

acoufelt.com
(Time: 45mins)

Hi Criselda,

I have great news - the tracking is now fixed, tested, and live.

I popped into the account and found the root cause. It turns out the "Custom Code" we added wasn't firing because the forms were reloading the page too quickly.

The Fix: Instead of forcing the website code to change, I simply "rewired" GTM to listen to the automatic signal that Google was already receiving but ignoring.
  • Variable Updated: I pointed GTM to read the correct data path (eventModel.form_id ).
  • Triggers Updated: The tags now correctly distinguish between the Contact Form (gform_3 ) and the Newsletter (gform_1 ).
  • Parameters Added: As requested, the Contact tag now sends contact_form  and the Newsletter tag sends newsletter .

Result: I tested both forms with live submissions, and the tags are firing perfectly with the correct data. You will start seeing this populate in your GA4 reports.

Let me know if you need anything else!

Thanks Adriane

I've already sent an invite to the email address.

Please note that for the Newsletter event tag, I tried to change the value to {{DLV - Form ID}} but it also didn't work.

Also, if we can have the form_name added - contact_form and newsletter

Warm regards,

Criselda Romero
Digital Marketing Manager

2 Jackstaff Court, Bayswater North, VIC, 3153

Hi Criselda,

Thanks for the update!

Since we confirmed the website is sending the data correctly, the issue is just a tiny mismatch between what the Tag expects to see versus what it is actually seeing.

The GTM Preview tool has a "Report Card" that tells us exactly why it said no. Could you please send me one specific screenshot?

How to find the "Red X":
  1. In the GTM Preview window, verify you submitted the form.
  2. On the left sidebar, click the form_submit event.
  3. In the main section, click the Tag that failed (under "Tags Not Fired").
  4. Scroll down to the section called "Firing Triggers".

What to look for: You will see a list of conditions. One of them will have a Red X next to it.
  • It might show that the Variable is still "undefined".
  • Or it might show that the value gform_3  didn't match the rule.

If you can snag a screenshot of that Firing Triggers section with the Red X, I may be able to tell you the exact fix.

Hi Adriane

No worries.

I updated the trigger rule and was also able to confirm that the data layer variable name is correct but no tags were fired again.

Warm regards,

Criselda Romero
Digital Marketing Manager



T: +61 1800 626 462
2 Jackstaff Court, Bayswater North, VIC, 3153
acoufelt.com
(Time: 15mins)

Hi Criselda,

Apologies for the delay in getting back to you!

That is excellent detective work. Checking the Data Layer tab was exactly the right move.

This gives us the final pieces of the puzzle:
  1. The Code is working (Yay!): The fact that you see form_id  with values like gform_3  in the Data Layer tab means the website is successfully sending the data.
  2. Why the Variable says "undefined": This confirms that GTM is either looking for the wrong "name," OR the Preview mode just needs a refresh to recognize your new variable.

Here is the 2-minute fix to get it firing:
Step 1: Double-check the Variable Name Go to your Variables list and open your user-defined variable (likely named DLV - Form ID ).
  • Look at the field called Data Layer Variable Name.
  • Ensure it is typed exactly as: form_id  (all lowercase, no spaces).
  • (Your screenshot looked correct, but it’s worth a quick check to ensure no extra spaces crept in!)

Step 2: Update the Trigger Rule Since you discovered the website sends the ID as gform_3  (instead of just the number 3 ), we need to update your trigger rule to match that text exactly.
  • Change: DLV - Form ID  equals 3
  • To: DLV - Form ID  equals gform_3

Step 3: Refresh the Preview (Important!) Sometimes the "undefined" error happens simply because the Preview window is holding onto an old version of the container.
  • Close your current debug tabs.
  • Click Preview in GTM again to launch a fresh session.

Once you update that Trigger to gform_3  and refresh the preview, that tag should fire perfectly.

Hi Adriane

I also checked the Data Layer tab, and the values that appear for form_id are - gform_1 and gform_3

Warm regards,

Criselda Romero
Digital Marketing Manager

Hi Criselda,

Thank you for sending those screenshots - they tell us exactly what is happening!

This is actually a very common scenario. You are seeing a mix of "Automatic" tracking versus your "Custom" GTM tracking.

1. Why you see data in GA4 (The "Automatic" part) The form_submit  events you see in your GA4 DebugView are likely coming from Google’s "Enhanced Measurement".
  • In simple terms: GA4 has a built-in feature that tries to automatically spot any form submission on a website. It saw you submit a form, so it recorded it. That explains why the data appears there!
2. Why the GTM Tag didn't fire (The "Custom" part) In your GTM screenshot, the "Contact Form Submission" tag didn't fire. This actually suggests your logic is working correctly, not failing!
  • The Rule: You told this tag: "Only fire if the Form ID is exactly 3 (The Contact Us form)."
  • The Test: If you happened to test the Newsletter (which is ID 1) instead of the Contact form, GTM correctly stopped the tag from firing because the ID didn't match the rule.

How to confirm this (The "Sherlock Holmes" check): You can see exactly what ID GTM "saw" during your test:
  1. In that GTM Preview window (from your screenshot), look at the left sidebar and click on the event #20 form_submit.
  2. Click the Variables tab in the main panel.
    Scroll down to find your variable (e.g., form_id  or DLV - Form ID ).
    • If the value is 1: You tested the Newsletter! This means your setup is perfect; you just need to duplicate the tag/trigger if you want to track the newsletter separately.
    • If the value is 3: Then the tag should have fired, and we can investigate further.

Let me know what number you see in that Variables tab!

Hi Adriane

I tested this in GTM Preview mode but the tags did not fire again but when I checked GA4 DebugView, looks like it came through.



Warm regards,

Criselda Romero
Digital Marketing Manager

Hi Criselda,

You are spot on!

You can leave that setting exactly as it is: Version 2.

That is the standard default for Google Tag Manager and ensures it can read the data correctly. You don't need to change anything else there.

You are all set to save and publish.

(Time: 15mins)

Hi Criselda,

Thanks for the screenshot - that is super helpful!

This is a very common "gotcha" in GTM. The Built-In variable you selected (called "Form ID") is designed to work with standard GTM listeners, but it is effectively "blind" to the custom Gravity Forms code we added to your site. It won't be able to "hear" the specific ID number we are sending.

To fix this, you just need to create a User-Defined Variable to catch that custom data.
Here is how to do it:
  1. In GTM, go to Variables.
  2. Scroll down to the User-Defined Variables section (below the Built-In list) and click New.
    Variable Configuration:
    • Variable Type: Data Layer Variable
    • Data Layer Variable Name: form_id  (Enter this exactly, all lowercase).
  3. Name the Variable: Call it something unique, like DLV - Form ID .
  4. Click Save.

Final Step: Now, just pop back into your Tag and Trigger and swap out the old {{Form ID}}  for your new {{DLV - Form ID}} .

Once you do that, you should be 100% ready to publish.

Thanks Adriane

I've updated the tag but for the trigger, I selected {{Form ID}} from the list of built-in variables.

Warm regards,

Criselda Romero
Digital Marketing Manager
